dt: used reflexively, for emphasis, or in absolute constructions

dt.t: {wi}themselves{/wi} busy, they disliked idleness in others

dt: used with an indefinite third person singular antecedent

dt.t: were {wi}themselves{/wi} again after a night's rest

usages.pl: Can {parahw}they{/parahw} be used as an indefinite subject?
pt: {it}They{/it} used as an indefinite subject (sense 2) is sometimes objected to on the grounds that it does not have an antecedent. Not every pronoun requires an antecedent, however. The indefinite {it}they{/it} is used in all varieties of contexts and is standard.

usages.pl: Can {parahw}they{/parahw}, {parahw}their{/parahw}, {parahw}them{/parahw}, and {parahw}themselves{/parahw} be used as singular pronouns?
pt: {it}They, their, them, themselves:{/it} English lacks a common-gender third person singular pronoun that can be used to refer to indefinite pronouns (such as {it}everyone, anyone, someone{/it}). Writers and speakers have supplied this lack by using the plural pronouns.

pt.t: and every one to rest {it}themselves{/it} betake
I would have everybody marry if {it}they{/it} can do it properly
it is too hideous for anyone in {it}their{/it} senses to buy

pt: The plural pronouns have also been put to use as pronouns of indefinite number to refer to singular nouns that stand for many persons.

pt.t: 'tis meet that some more audience than a mother, since nature makes {it}them{/it} partial, should o'erhear the speech
no man goes to battle to be killed.—But {it}they{/it} do get killed

pt: The use of {it}they, their, them{/it}, and {it}themselves{/it} as pronouns of indefinite gender and indefinite number is well established in speech and writing, even in literary and formal contexts. In recent years, these pronouns have also been adopted by individuals whose gender identity is nonbinary, as illustrated in sense 3d above.

shortdef: those identical ones that are they —used reflexively, for emphasis, or in absolute constructions
himself or herself : himself, herself —used with an indefinite third person singular antecedent
their normal, healthy, or sane condition

dt: used to say that the facts connected with a matter make the matter clear

dt.t: There's no doubt that he did it. {it}The facts speak for themselves{/it}.

dt: {bc}a record of debit {dx_def}see {dxt|debit:2||1a}{/dx_def} and credit {dx_def}see {dxt|credit:1||2d}{/dx_def} entries to cover transactions involving a particular item or a particular person or concern
{bc}a statement of transactions during a fiscal period and the resulting balance

dt.t: She was asked to give an {wi}account{/wi} of her actions.

dt: {bc}a statement or exposition of reasons, causes, or motives
{bc}a formal business arrangement providing for regular dealings or services (such as banking, advertising, or store credit) and involving the establishment and maintenance of an account

dt.t: They are one of our most important {wi}accounts{/wi}.

dt: {bc}money deposited in a bank account and subject to withdrawal by the depositor
{bc}an arrangement in which a person uses the Internet or email services of a particular company

dt.t: factoring all of these issues into {wi}account{/wi}

dt: {bc}a description of facts, conditions, or events {bc}{sx|report||}, {sx|narrative||}

dros.drp: give a good account of oneself

dt: {bc}to perform well especially in a competition or confrontation {bc}to acquit oneself well

dt.t: Though he has an aristocratic bearing, he could probably {wi}give a good account of himself{/wi} in a street fight.

dt: {bc}with the price charged to one's account

dt.t: The game was cancelled {it}on account of{/it} rain.
{it}On no account{/it} should the children be left alone at home.
I'm doing it {it}on my own account{/it}, not for anyone else.

et: Middle English {it}acounte, accompt{/it}, borrowed from Anglo-French {it}acunte, acounte{/it}, noun derivative of {it}acunter{/it} "to {et_link|account:2|account:2}"
shortdef: a record of debit and credit entries to cover transactions involving a particular item or a particular person or concern
a statement of transactions during a fiscal period and the resulting balance
reckoning, computation

dt: {bc}to state or declare positively and often forcefully or aggressively

dt.t: The suspect continued to {wi}assert{/wi} his innocence.

dt: {bc}to compel or demand acceptance or recognition of (something, such as one's authority)

dt.t: … the confrontations that inevitably occur [between orangutans] when several males try to {wi}assert{/wi} dominance …
Wallace {wi}asserted{/wi} control early—shutting down both candidates when they tried to talk over one another, and shushing the audience when it reacted too audibly.
He wished to vindicate himself in some way, to {wi}assert{/wi} his manhood.

dt: {bc}to speak or act in a manner that compels recognition especially of one's rights

dt.t: … she wants him to learn to {wi}assert himself{/wi} with people in positions of authority.
… a long-suffering Irish community {wi}asserted itself{/wi} by putting its own politicians in power.

dt: {bc}to become more strongly apparent {bc}to become clearly seen, known, or experienced

dt.t: Unbidden, a glint {wi}asserts itself{/wi} in Ms. Brown's eyes …
… a passion that through its long suppression was now {wi}asserting itself{/wi} with volcanic necessity.

pt: {sc}assert{/sc} {sc}declare{/sc} {sc}affirm{/sc} {sc}protest{/sc} {sc}avow{/sc} mean to state positively usually in anticipation of denial or objection. {sc}assert{/sc} implies stating confidently without need for proof or regard for evidence.

pt.t: {it}asserted{/it} that modern music is just noise

pt: {sc}affirm{/sc} implies conviction based on evidence, experience, or faith.
{sc}protest{/sc} emphasizes affirming in the face of denial or doubt.

pt.t: {it}protested{/it} that he really had been misquoted

pt: {sc}avow{/sc} stresses frank declaration and acknowledgment of personal responsibility for what is declared.

pt.t: {it}avowed{/it} that all investors would be repaid in full

et: Latin {it}assertus{/it}, past participle of {it}asserere{/it}, from {it}ad-{/it} + {it}serere{/it} to join {ma}{mat|series|}{/ma}
shortdef: to state or declare positively and often forcefully or aggressively
to compel or demand acceptance or recognition of (something, such as one's authority)
to demonstrate the existence of

dt: {bc}to produce or result in as a benefit or advantage {bc}{sx|gain||}
{bc}to make use of {bc}to take advantage of

quotes.t: Soon middle-class girls were slipping into their starched white shirtwaists, marching into a place of business … and eventually standing up as private secretaries, bank tellers, accountants, and managers. So many, in fact, {qword}availed{/qword} themselves of this new opportunity that by 1900 nearly 75 percent of all clerical workers in America were women (Bliven puts the number, in 1888, at 60,000); and for decades the typist and her machine were both called "typewriters."
In such a Hobbesian world, grand idealistic designs will {qword}avail{/qword} the United States nothing. Nor will a quest for American dominance in the name of the good.
One comes away from the book stunned by the remarkable energy and willingness to resist that so many demonstrated but haunted by the recognition of how little that resistance {qword}availed{/qword}.

et: Middle English, Anglo-French {it}availler{/it}, probably from {it}a-{/it} (from Latin {it}ad-{/it}) + {it}valer, valoir{/it} to be of worth, from Latin {it}valēre{/it} {ma}{mat|wield|}{/ma}
shortdef: to be of use or advantage : serve
to produce or result in as a benefit or advantage : gain

dt.t: potential complications are minor {wi}beside{/wi} the benefits
a composition that can be ranked {wi}beside{/wi} that of the masters
learning other languages {wi}beside{/wi} French and English

et: Middle English, adverb & preposition, from Old English {it}be sīdan{/it} at or to the side, from {it}be{/it} at (from {it}bī{/it}) + {it}sīdan{/it}, dative & accusative of {it}sīde{/it} side {ma}{mat|by|}{/ma}
shortdef: by the side of
in comparison with
on a par with

dt: {bc}to move or journey to a vicinity with a specified purpose
{bc}to reach a particular station in a series

dt.t: Now we {wi}come{/wi} to the section on health.
The time has {wi}come{/wi} to make your decision.
{wi}came{/wi} to regard him as a friend
{wi}Come{/wi} to think of it, you may be right.

dt: {bc}to advance, rise, or improve in rank or condition
{bc}to arrive at a particular place, end, result, or conclusion

dt.t: The taxes on it {wi}come{/wi} to more than it's worth.

dt: {bc}to appear on a scene {bc}make an appearance

dt.t: Children {wi}come{/wi} equipped to learn any language.

dt: used in the subjunctive with inverted subject and verb to express the particular time or occasion

dt.t: {wi}Come{/wi} spring the days will be longer.

dt: {bc}to enter or assume a condition, position, or relation
{bc}to fall within a field of view or a range of application

dt.t: This {wi}comes{/wi} within the terms of the treaty.

dt: {bc}to fall to a person in a division or inheritance of property

dt.t: Several thousand dollars {wi}came{/wi} to him from his uncle.

dt: {bc}to meet, find, or encounter especially by chance

dt.t: Researchers have {it}come across{/it} important new evidence.

dt: {bc}to acquire as a possession or achievement

dt.t: He had a slow start as a pitcher, but he's {it}come into his own{/it} this season.
Your class has {it}come of age{/it} at a moment of great consequence for our nation and for the world …

dt: {bc}to cease foolish or pretentious talk or behavior

dt.t: When it {it}comes to{/it} pitching horseshoes, he's the champ.

dt: {bc}to encounter misfortune (such as calamity, defeat, or ruin)
{bc}to meet or deal with firmly, frankly, or straightforwardly

dt.t: {it}come to grips with{/it} the unemployment problem
But when he {it}came to himself{/it} he said, "How many of my father's hired servants have bread enough and to spare … "
Many of the things he predicted have {it}come to pass{/it}.
The company has {it}come to terms{/it} with the union.

dt: {bc}to become adjusted especially emotionally or intellectually
{bc}to meet or find by chance {bc}come across

dt.t: There will be more trouble {it}to come{/it}.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}cuman{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}queman{/it} to come, Latin {it}venire{/it}, Greek {it}bainein{/it} to walk, go
shortdef: to move toward something : approach
to move or journey to a vicinity with a specified purpose
to reach a particular station in a series

dt: {bc}to have for one's use, benefit, or lot {bc}{sx|experience||}

et: Middle English {it}enjoien{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}enjoir, enjoier{/it} to gladden, enjoy, from {it}en-{/it} + {it}joie{/it} joy
shortdef: to have a good time
to have for one's use, benefit, or lot : experience
to take pleasure or satisfaction in

dt: {bc}to give the reason for or cause of
{bc}to show the logical development or relationships of

dt.t: a report that suggests rather than {wi}explains{/wi}

dt: {bc}to clarify one's statements or the reasons for one's conduct

pt: {sc}explain{/sc} {sc}expound{/sc} {sc}explicate{/sc} {sc}elucidate{/sc} {sc}interpret{/sc} mean to make something clear or understandable. {sc}explain{/sc} implies a making plain or intelligible what is not immediately obvious or entirely known.
{sc}expound{/sc} implies a careful often elaborate explanation.
{sc}explicate{/sc} adds the idea of a developed or detailed analysis.
{sc}elucidate{/sc} stresses the throwing of light upon as by offering details or motives previously unclear or only implicit.
{sc}interpret{/sc} adds to {sc}explain{/sc} the need for imagination or sympathy or special knowledge in dealing with something.

et: Middle English {it}explanen{/it}, from Latin {it}explanare{/it}, literally, to make level, from {it}ex-{/it} + {it}planus{/it} level, flat {ma}{mat|floor|}{/ma}
shortdef: to make known
to make plain or understandable
to give the reason for or cause of

dt: {bc}to descend freely by the force of gravity
{bc}to drop oneself to a lower position
{bc}to come or go as if by {a_link|falling}
{bc}to become lower in degree or level
{bc}to leave an erect position suddenly and involuntarily

dt.t: after a long siege the city {it}fell{/it}
but man willfully misused his God-given freedom and {it}fell{/it} into sin

dt: {bc}to move or extend in a downward direction

dt.t: the land {wi}falls{/wi} away to the east

dt: {bc}to decline in quality, activity, or quantity

dt.t: The cattle have {it}fallen{/it} off badly in the drought.

dt: {bc}to assume a look of shame, disappointment, or dejection
{bc}to decline in financial value or price

dt.t: her birthday {wi}falls{/wi} on a Monday this year
a job that {it}fell{/it} into his hands

dt: {bc}to come or pass by lot, assignment, or inheritance {bc}{sx|devolve||}

dt.t: it {it}fell{/it} to him to break the news

dt: {bc}to have a certain or proper position, place, or station

dt.t: the accent {wi}falls{/wi} on the second syllable

dt: {bc}to come within the limits, scope, or jurisdiction of something

dt.t: this word {wi}falls{/wi} into the class of verbs

dt: {bc}to pass suddenly and passively into a state of body or mind or a new state or condition

dt.t: Fans were {it}falling all over themselves{/it} trying to get the basketball star's autograph.
The pie was {it}falling apart{/it} as I served it.

dt: {bc}to succumb to mental or emotional stress {bc}{sx|break down||}

dt.t: She began to {it}fall apart{/it} when her son was imprisoned.
The slower hikers {it}fell behind{/it} the group.
He {it}fell behind{/it} in his car payments.

dt: {bc}to fail because of inability to choose between or reconcile two alternative or conflicting courses of action

dt.t: He {it}fell for{/it} her the moment he saw her.
The governor {it}fell from grace{/it} when he was accused of tax fraud.

dt: used of the timbers or upper parts of a ship's side
{bc}to comply with a certain course of action

dt.t: The company {it}fell into line{/it} with the new regulations.
the movie {it}fell on its face{/it} at the box office
The coach {it}fell on his sword{/it} apologizing for the team's poor season.
The expedition's supplies began to {it}fall short{/it}.

dt: {bc}to fail to attain something (such as a goal or target)

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}feallan{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}fallan{/it} to fall and perhaps to Lithuanian {it}pulti{/it}
shortdef: to descend freely by the force of gravity
to hang freely
to drop oneself to a lower position
